body: In his gray three-piece suit and crisp white shirt, Wayne Knight cuts a dapper figure. But the veneer crumbles when Mr. Knight, 49, is asked to recall the lowest point in his life: sleeping on the No. 2 train when he had run out of money and could not bring himself to impose on his family. ''I am not afraid to tell you, I hit rock bottom,'' he
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Back From Rock Bottom, and Protecting Others Again

author: E-mail: haberman@nytimes.com
body: On the first day of Christmas, your true love gives you a partridge in a pear tree. That's what the old English carol says, anyway. But just try pulling that off in New York City. First, you need a true love, and this is a city filled with many lonely people. Let's not even go there. Better to stick to the material objects. ''My New York City
title: NYC; Easier Sung Than Purchased: Partridge, Etc.

body: HIRSCH--Morton P.E.,Educator, Entrepreneur, Inventor, Manufacturer and Fire Protection Pioneer, dies at 73. Morton (Morti) Hirsch P.E. of New York City, passed away on Friday, December 18, 2009 while conducting business in Florida. His illustrious career was known worldwide by members of the fire protection community. He founded the Active Fire
title: Paid Notice: Deaths HIRSCH, MORTON P.E.

body: MANY blocks in Midwood, with its rows of orderly detached homes and private driveways, give the feeling of a carefully planned suburb -- a serene surprise after turning off a thoroughfare like Coney Island Avenue or Ocean Parkway. But closer inspection reveals that the landscape has, in fact, been altered: on virtually every block, at least one or
title: LIVING IN | MIDWOOD, BROOKLYN; Where Prosperity Breeds Proximity

body: There is TriBeCa as a bucolic meadow and craggy hill in a 1763 engraving; Brooklyn looking like a sleepy upstate village in 1817; the Great Fire of 1835 consuming practically all of Manhattan's business district; a 21-million-gallon walled reservoir where the New York Public Library now stands; the progenitor of Brooks Brothers looking like a poky
title: HOLIDAY BOOKS; The City

body: The unmarked gym dares boxers to find it, and promises nothing fancy when they do: an assortment of exercise machines, half a dozen punching bags and a lone ring. It was once an old clothing factory on Fourth Avenue in Sunset Park, near the border between the row houses and the forsaken factories of Brooklyn. There is no sign for the Ardon Sweet
title: Trading Punches, and Mending Lives

body: Leslie Jackson is ready for her close-up. ''When I get back on my feet, there's no stopping me,'' she said one rainy Friday. ''Grandma Moses waited until she was 80 -- that won't be me.'' Ms. Jackson, 54, is off her feet and away from her desired profession -- acting and voice-over work -- because of a tumble she took down the stairs almost three
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; A Fall Was Instant; Recovery Drags On

body: This year, the numbers of those feeling themselves among the neediest have stretched, like the wallets of the city itself. To the ranks of those who have needed food, or clothing, or a place to live, or a prosthetic limb, or an electric wheelchair, add Dion Lewis. He needed a job. He needed training he could not afford. He needed to have his
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Feeding a Hunger for Skills, and Finding a Future

body: In London, Paris and Washington, subway riders need only look up at a digital sign to know how many minutes it will be until the next train arrives. New York's straphangers usually resort to peering into a darkened tunnel. But for some riders in the Bronx, that often-futile search for a headlight is about to end. New York City Transit announced on
title: Countdown Clocks for 3 Stations

body: THE house that Michael and Lori Hiller planned to buy in South Park Slope, Brooklyn, was a good size for the neighborhood, and on a pleasant block. But then a problem developed with the building's certificate of occupancy. Since Mrs. Hiller had been the bigger fan of Park Slope, it was Mr. Hiller who had more zest for a new search. He found himself
title: LIVING IN | DITMAS PARK, BROOKLYN; Moved for the Space; Stayed for the Food

body: Millie Ahrham Shin and Max Benjamin Tourtelot were married Friday. Rabbi Richard A. Davis officiated at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in Manhattan. Mrs. Tourtelot, 30, is the director of Christian education and discipleship at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in Manhattan. She received both a bachelor's and a master's degree in linguistics
title: Millie Shin, Benjamin Tourtelot

body: It's not uncommon for teenagers to flock to the mall at the end of a school day. But something went awry on Tuesday, when thousands of high school students descended on the Atlantic Center Mall in Brooklyn and a stabbing and shootings followed. In this case, the police pinned the commotion on -- of all things -- a 40-cent chicken wing promotion at
title: A 40-Cent Wings Special and Gunfire

body: DAN SCHREIBER and Caroline Jeanjot took a one-bedroom sublet in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, after arriving in New York three years ago from their native Brussels. They chose it because of its low monthly rent, around $1,200, but knew little about the city's geography. Their Bay Ridge neighborhood was ideal in all ways but one -- the tedious subway ride to
title: THE HUNT; Going With Uncool

body: Over the past seven years, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has presided over a historic re-envisioning of New York City, one that loosened the reins on development across the boroughs and pushed more than 100 rezoning measures through a City Council that stamped them all into law. His administration poured $16 billion into financing to foster commercial
title: A Stalled Vision: Big Development As City's Future

body: A string of 12 row houses built between 1909 and 1918 along Ocean Avenue, across from Prospect Park in Flatbush, Brooklyn, became a historic district on Tuesday by a unanimous vote of the Landmarks Preservation Commission. The 8-to-0 vote to create the Ocean on the Park Historic District gives landmark protection to the houses, which sit on land
title: CITY ROOM BLOGGING AT NYTIMES.COM/CITYROOM.; Flatbush Houses Declared Historic

author: Alana Joblin Ain is a writer and an adjunct instructor at Hunter College, where she received an M.F.A. in poetry.
body: I BOUNDED off the Q train in Brooklyn one night last winter and headed to Union Street, past the yogurt shop and the firehouse, to do some grocery shopping. But my plans soon went awry. ''You're suspended,'' the entrance worker at the Park Slope Food Coop announced as I swiped my membership card. Some entrance workers speak softly, but not this
title: Flunking Out at the Food Co-op

body: LITTLE CAKES cupcake shop was a dream slow-baking in the mind of Christina Pappas Dearborn. Her childhood wish to open a bakery was overtaken by a fast-track finance career: At 22, she was trading on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange; by 24, she had her first ulcer; in 2007, she retired from Wall Street at the ripe age of 27. It took two
title: OPEN & SHUT; Chronicle of a Changing City

body: Jay H. Walder, the new chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, was walking through his old neighborhood in Brooklyn on Monday when he ran into a former neighbor he had not seen in 15 years. Pleasantries were quickly followed by a plea: ''Please do something about the B41!'' That would be the B41 bus, which Megan Ryan, 65, the former
title: Lanes for Buses Only, and New M.T.A. Chief Means It

body: A fire in a Queens apartment building early Sunday left a 44-year-old woman dead and three others critically injured, the authorities said. The two-alarm blaze began shortly after 3 a.m. in Apartment 5A at the Pomonok Houses, a public housing complex on 71st Avenue in Flushing. It tore through the apartment, but the cement and steel walls stopped
title: One Dead and Three Hurt In Queens Apartment Fire

body: Open Now BAR CELONA The name is clever and, of course, there are tapas on the menu of this lounge, which is owned by Cynthia Diaz, left, a fashion consultant who has done her place in Dolce & Gabbana black and gold. The chef, Jordy Lavanderos, goes beyond Spain for his inspiration with scallop ceviche, mackerel paté and mushroom tostones: 104
title: Off the Menu

body: At the end of a dark passageway at the Port Authority Bus Terminal, almost 50 artworks have suddenly parked in a bright, spare gallery. On a grim stretch of the Flatbush Avenue Extension in Brooklyn, pastel portraits and interactive sculptures are squeezed between a McDonald's and an Applebee's. In the window of a former dentist's office in
title: Luring Artists to Lend Life to Empty Storefronts

body: HALLOWEEN AT THE A-SCARIUM Many Halloween celebrations focus on frightening creatures that travel by air: wayward spirits, witches on broomsticks, vampires disguised as bats. Leave it to the New York Aquarium to take the concept well below sea level. ''We don't have goblins or ghosts or Frankensteins,'' said Judy Frimer, director of marketing for
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: In the early evening of May 27, 1911, an electric light fell into hot tar and exploded on the Dreamland amusement pier at Coney Island. Overnight, the pier's ornate white buildings, restaurants, thrill rides, ballroom and tents -- which attracted 40,000 people a day -- were vaporized in the ensuing fire, said Charles Denson, a Coney Island
title: After 98 Years Underwater, a Coney Island Bell Is Back

body: ONE-WORD BATTLE Amid an Election Jimmy McMillan is running for mayor of New York City. The fact that few in the city are aware of his existence, much less his candidacy, did not deter him as he swaggered down Utica Avenue in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, on a recent evening, greeting each person walking by and reminding them to vote. ''Hey, how are you
title: City Room Blogging at NYTIMES.COM/CITYROOM.

body: Edina Tokodi inspects her work -- a portrait made of wood and succulent plants -- on the wall at a rooftop at 33 Flatbush Avenue, where Green Spaces, a group that provides work space for environmentally conscious entrepreneurs, has offices in Downtown Brooklyn. Previous installments of Sight/Site, which examines public art, are available at
title: LENS; Sight/Site

body: BARK HOT DOGS 474 Bergen Street (Flatbush Avenue), Park Slope, Brooklyn; (718) 789-1939. Bark Hot Dogs, which has been working out its kinks since last month, takes a fearless leap into the ever-closing gap between artisan chic and fast food. The hot dogs, which start at $4 and come in a well-griddled, top-loading bun a pleasant size too small, are
title: DINING BRIEFS; RECENTLY OPENED

body: An off-duty police officer was charged on Sunday with vehicular manslaughter and driving while intoxicated after, according to the police and relatives, the sport utility vehicle he was driving struck and killed a Brooklyn woman who was hailing a taxi. The officer, Andrew Kelly, 30, a seven-year veteran of the Police Department who worked in the
title: Woman Killed Hailing Cab; Officer Held In Accident

body: Mel Vader and Bob Henderson figured that martini hour on the terrace of their apartment in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, would grow only more interesting after Richard Meier built his 15-story glass tower across the way. From their sixth-floor perch, the couple have seen a toddler on the eighth floor ride her tricycle around her balcony, and watched
title: Glass Half Empty

body: Scholars are not sure what Margrieta van Varick looked like, or even how she spelled her name, even though she ran a successful furnishings import business in Dutch New York. In her meager surviving paperwork from the 1690s the name variants include Margrita, Grietje and Magret. What is known is exactly how many ebony-framed mirrors, silver-headed
title: ANTIQUES; Old Dutch New York

body: NEW YORK CITY CRICKET CRAWL This Friday evening New York families are invited to listen closely to the city's most unheralded street musicians. Not guys who stand on subway platforms and neighborhood corners, playing insistently (and not always tunefully) for change. These are more retiring types, unfailing in their rhythm but easily crushed --
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: To say that the 22-acre Atlantic Yards development project in Brooklyn is in disarray is not a major revelation. That it may still be possible to save -- and may even be worth saving -- comes as news. When Bruce Ratner, the project's developer, fired Frank Gehry last year -- after getting city approval on the basis of Mr. Gehry's design -- and
title: ARCHITECTURE REVIEW | ATLANTIC YARDS; New Yards Design Draws From the Old

body: With only 10 days left in the primary race for New York City's second-highest elected office, most of the candidates in the running for public advocate still seem to be introducing themselves. Bill de Blasio, a councilman from Brooklyn, has enlisted more than 40 prominent surrogates, like Representative Yvette D. Clarke, to act as de facto press
title: In Race for Advocate, Each Candidate Has His Own Approach

body: It's said that every vote counts. This is particularly true of a number of City Council races in New York City on Sept. 15, when a few hundred votes could determine who will occupy a front-row seat in city government. Here are our endorsements for several of the most competitive districts where winning the Democratic primary usually means capturing
title: EDITORIAL; For New York City Council

title: CRITICAL SHOPPER | JONATHAN ADLER; Take a Sunrise, Sprinkle It With Dew

title: RESTAURANTS; Good Tips at the End of His Meals

title: School Buses May Give Older New Yorkers a Lift

body: Homesick Godzilla Q.The Brooklyn Botanic Garden used to have a huge resident snapping turtle named Godzilla. Is he still there? A. Godzilla is alive and well, but he's been moved across Flatbush Avenue to Prospect Park. And therein lies a story, as related by Eugene Patron, a spokesman for the Prospect Park Alliance, with contributions from Leeann
title: F.Y.I.

title: Stimulus Aid Planned for Two City Projects

title: FOOD STUFF; Hey, Hot Dogs (and Rustic Charm) Here!

body: DMC USA D.J. FINALS Beck and Kanye West are musicians who on the surface have little in common. Beck is a subgenre-hopping rock musician who first gained notice with the depression-inducing song ''Loser,'' while Kanye West's real-life chest-thumping boasts are almost as memorable as those in his rhymes. But when looking for accompaniment to their
title: Spare Times

body: A fire that tore through a wood-frame house in Brooklyn on Sunday morning left two men dead, the authorities said. ''The house was engulfed in flames, it was crazy, there was fire everywhere,'' said Jana Sonny, who lives a few blocks from the two-story house, at 3920 Avenue K, off Flatbush Avenue. ''Even standing on the street you could feel the
title: A Fierce Brooklyn Fire Kills Two Men

body: New York City shopping is less associated with malls than with Madison Avenue flagships, SoHo boutiques, East Village storefronts and Chinatown sidewalks. But there are indeed malls in the city, and these days they are offering more than run-of-the-mill amenities. WEST SIDE At the Shops at Columbus Circle in Manhattan, Borders Books and Music
title: In the City, Children's Clubs and Walking to Shape Up

body: NEW YORK CITY opened its first municipal airport in May 1931 with a grand ceremony for Floyd Bennett Field, at the end of Flatbush Avenue where the eastern fringe of Brooklyn meets Jamaica Bay. A crowd of thousands craned their necks and held on to their hats as fighter planes staged mock battles against an overcast sky and an armada of bombers
title: WEEKEND EXPLORER; Where New Yorkers First Took Flight

title: SPARE TIMES

body: 1. MOTORINO319 Graham Avenue (Devoe Street), Williamsburg, Brooklyn; (718) 599-8899. Pros: Properly cooked Neapolitan crusts with character and no soupiness. title: The Best New-Generation Pizzerias

title: For Children

body: Selling the name of a subway station has been a goal of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority for nearly five years. But interest has been low, even for a piece of real estate so recognizable to the public. So it was with surprisingly little fanfare that the authority announced on Monday that it had finally found a buyer. If a $4 million deal
title: M.T.A. Sells the Naming Rights to a Station, and Wants to Make More Deals

body: Shops selling prepared food that I would be happy to serve are about as rare as the spotted owl. But I am adding Bklyn Larder to the short list. This simple store is drawing customers to its homemade sausages and house-cured meats. But it is dishes like boned lamb stuffed with herbs, buttery boned and stuffed porchetta, and fresh peas drizzled with
title: FOOD STUFF; Prepared Food With a Difference

title: THE LISTINGS

body: David Adjmi, whose play ''Stunning'' at the Duke on 42nd Street will be his professional New York theater debut on Thursday, bit into a slice at the Di Fara Pizza parlor. Great food and bad history met in that recent moment of triumphant homecoming. When Mr. Adjmi, now 36, was a student years ago at the nearby Yeshivah of Flatbush in the Midwood
title: Once a Boyhood Outsider, Now Reflecting on His Tribe

body: The Cougars of Middle School 61 had a basketball game in the Bronx, but a half-hour before tipoff, six girls and Coach Bryan Mariner were still inching through traffic in Brooklyn. A cellphone rang. It belonged to forward Tiffany Fields-Binning, who passed the phone to Mr. Mariner. ''You don't want her to go?'' he said. He peered up at a street
title: LEFT BEHIND; A City Team's Struggle Shows Disparity in Girls' Sports

body: As some elected officials wrestled Sunday with the racial implications of a police shooting that left a black officer dead and a white one devastated, a bereaved relative -- himself a member of the New York police force -- struggled between grief and understanding. ''My heart goes out to him,'' said William Glenn, the father-in-law of Omar J.
title: Coping With Police Shooting, and Working to Avoid a Repeat

body: JAPAN DAY In Japan no occasion is too small to warrant a gift. A visit to a friend, the signing of a lease or a return from a short trip is accompanied by a small token or simple cash. So it is no surprise that in 1912 the Japanese saw fit to send cherry trees to cities in the United States, including New York, where some took root in Central Park.
title: SPARE TIMES

body: DANCE Full reviews of recent performances: nytimes.com/dance. title: THE LISTINGS

body: For Danie, who moved from Port-au-Prince, Haiti, to the United States in 2001 to live with her grandparents, there has never been a good time to go home. Haiti, which has stumbled from grave political unrest to catastrophic natural disasters, remains one of the world's poorest nations. So although Danie, 22, is an illegal immigrant, she has decided
title: Haitians Here Illegally Study Rumors for Signs Of Pause in Deportation

body: THEY said nothing could replace Mooney's Pub. For almost a year, they were right. The old bar, which had stood on Flatbush Avenue near Seventh Avenue in Prospect Heights since before Brooklyn was fashionable, closed in a rent dispute last June, after a rollicking Saturday night when the air-conditioning broke and people crowded in anyway. The next
title: DISPATCHES; A Bar -- a Bar! -- Where the Pub Used to Be

body: Address: 83 Lefferts Avenue (between Flatbush and Bedford Avenues), Brooklyn The Property: A 1920s two-story semidetached brick house with an English basement, driveway and one-car garage. The house has three bedrooms, three and a half baths, a stylish open living-dining-kitchen space with exposed beams, and central air-conditioning. Annual taxes
title: BUY OF THE WEEK/PROSPECT-LEFFERTS GARDENS; $895,000

body: Myra Alperson is a matchmaker of sorts. She brings together people curious about exploring the city and introduces them to out-of-the-way neighborhoods they may never have visited. And like Napoleon's army, her crew travels on its stomach. An effervescent and ambulatory Zagat, Ms. Alperson has for 10 years run culinary tours that she calls
title: BAY RIDGE JOURNAL; Changing Tastes, From Lingonberry to Baba Ghanouj

author: Information about events to be considered for inclusion in Spare Times can be sent to weekend@nytimes.com.
body: WALL TO WALL BROADWAY Since Symphony Space presented Wall to Wall Bach, a free 12-hour event, as its first offering in 1978, many more such music and discussion marathons have followed, honoring composers from Schumann and Stravinsky to musical theater types including Irving Berlin and Stephen Sondheim. But the occasion planned for Saturday may be
title: SPARE TIMES

body: Less than a day after his arrest over a confrontation with a newspaper photographer, State Senator Kevin S. Parker of Brooklyn was stripped of his leadership positions on Saturday, said a spokesman for the Senate majority leader, Malcolm A, Smith. Mr. Parker was arrested on Friday night after the police said he had chased down the photographer,
title: After Arrest, a State Senator Loses His Leadership Posts

body: IN September, New Yorkers will celebrate the quadricentennial of Henry Hudson's voyage, and if you ever wondered what Hudson encountered when he arrived, you can turn for answers to Eric W. Sanderson, who reimagines 1609 Manhattan in stunning and exuberant detail. Mr. Sanderson, a senior ecologist at the Wildlife Conservation Society, has
title: READING NEW YORK; Tours,Tycoons and Crazy Joe

body: WITH turrets, a notched roofline and an adorning lion-themed coat of arms, the stone-walled home at National Drive and Indiana Place in Mill Basin is a dead ringer for a castle. But as recently as the mid-20th century, when this tucked-away southeast Brooklyn neighborhood was considered the borough's frontier, the only castles to be found were most
title: LIVING IN | MILL BASIN, BROOKLYN; Mill's Long Gone, but the Basin's Still Full

body: 'TREASURE ISLAND' Manhattan isn't an island where you look for buried treasure. But unexpected gold can be discovered there now, both in a downtown show and in the enterprising troupe presenting it. That company is Literally Alive Children's Theater, whose ''Treasure Island'' offers riches beyond the plot's pieces of eight. For children whose idea
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: NEW YORK CITY UPPER EAST SIDE, THROUGH MAY 17 The 2009 Kips Bay Decorator Show House is at a 1927 limestone mansion at 22 East 71st Street. The hours are 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Monday to Saturday; (until 8 p.m. on Tuesday and Thursday); Sunday, noon to 5 p.m. Participating designers will include Charlotte Moss, Juan Montoya, Christopher Corcoran,
title: New York City

body: THE season of house tours, garden tours and show houses is here, when visitors are invited into skinny row houses, sprawling apartments and vast estates to study their gleaming kitchens, burnished woodwork, antiques and artworks and city or country views. Unless otherwise noted, tours are self-guided; details may change, so check with a tour's
title: Homes and Gardens, Open for Gawking

body: AROUND TOWN THE RASPBERRY BROTHERS Cultural recycling continues apace. A year after ''Mystery Science Theater 3000'' went off the air, Jeremy Pollet, a New York-born performer known to his friends as Jerm, started a similar event at a big independent theater in Austin, Tex. Like ''Mystery Science Theater,'' his group, the Raspberry Brothers, poked
title: Spare Times

body: NORVAL WHITE, one of the great figures of New York architecture, was cruising around Long Island City a couple of months ago when he came upon an unexpected sight. On Jackson Avenue, in this still scrappy-looking section of Queens, stood a newish co-op sheathed in luminous squares of blue glass. Its designer, Robert Scarano Jr., is one of the less
title: The Grand Cornice-and-Pediment Tour

body: 'FOOD IN FILM: An Evening of Flavors From the Silver Screen' Good films, like good lasagna, are artfully layered productions, filled with metaphors and surprises. How filmmakers develop food scenes will be tastefully dissected on Wednesday night in this program at the 92nd Street Y, part of the series Francine Segan's World of Tasting. Ms. Segan, a
title: Spare Times

body: 'THE FROG AND THE WITCH' Fairy-tale villains usually do evil in familiar ways, whether it's imprisoning maidens, cursing newborns or turning princes into frogs. But the sorceress in Vital Children's Theater's latest musical practices wickedness the Grimms probably never thought of: she pollutes the ecosystem. The show, ''The Frog and the Witch,''
title: Spare Times: For Children

author: Nelson George's book ''City Kid: A Writer's Memoir of Ghetto Life and Post-Soul Success'' will be published this month by Viking.
body: ON a recent unusually mild Saturday, I strolled around Fort Greene, Brooklyn, and, perhaps because of my respectable salt-and-pepper goatee, several folks asked me for directions. An affable white couple on bikes wanted to know how to get to Williamsburg; a young hipster asked me which way to the Alibi Club, the Pratt Institute hangout. I got a
title: NEW YORK OBSERVED; Strangers on His Street

body: AROUND TOWN UNIVERSOUL CIRCUS This year's theme of change has proved infectious. body: In the age of Madoff, in the age of bailouts, in the age of layoffs, comes the unprecedented spectacle of not one, but two heavily subsidized baseball stadiums opening in New York in the very same week. It is instructive that the Yankees have seen fit to bring in the Cubs and the Mets are welcoming the Red Sox, two ancient franchises that exist --
title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES; Where Retro Meets Recession

body: Two people were shot to death inside a bodega in Brooklyn on Wednesday night, the police said. The shooting occurred around 9:45 p.m. inside a shop at 309 Utica Avenue in Flatbush, the authorities said. The police were unable to say if the victims were employees, patrons or suspects. One man was killed at the scene, and another was pronounced dead
title: 2 Men Shot to Death In a Brooklyn Bodega

body: A small group of Democratic state senators from Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx have blocked a financial rescue proposal for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority because it would require tolls on the East River and Harlem River bridges. They have taken this position even though the plan is meant to help hold down transit fares, and in their
title: Unlikely Opponents of Bridge Tolls: Transit Riders

author: E-mail: fyi@nytimes.com
body: As Cheap as Water Q.Eight ounces of Poland Spring (plus a nice plastic bottle) costs about a dollar. How much does the same amount straight from the tap cost? I mean, how much does it really cost? A. One two-thousandth as much, according to the city's Department of Environmental Protection. Both the mayor and the City Council have voiced their
title: F. Y. I.

body: AROUND TOWN BEARD AND MUSTACHE CHAMPIONSHIP Facial hair may be de rigueur in certain irony-loving neighborhoods in the city, but around the country it can still be a badge of ne'er-do-wells. ''We call it beardism,'' said Matthew Saccoman, a high school teacher from Meriden, Conn., known to his friends as Beardzzz. So when Mr. Saccoman, 31, came to
title: Spare Times

body: Where do I fit in? That question is a persistent theme in the jolly, seriously introspective pop music of the 47-year-old singer-songwriter Stew, a k a Mark Stewart. Flanked onstage by his longtime composing partner, Heidi Rodewald, who played bass, he gave the final concert of Lincoln Center's American Songbook season on Friday at Alice Tully
title: MUSIC REVIEW | STEW; The Bard of Identity Crisis, Singing About Strangers in Strange Lands

body: THE race begins at the intersection of Kings Highway and Flatbush Avenue in Flatlands, Brooklyn. ''This is where we clean up, gas up and hit the street,'' said Osmond Thorne, his white 14-passenger van idling at the curb. Unlike nearly every other New Yorker, Mr. Thorne and his fellow drivers of Flatbush vans have been eagerly awaiting the
title: FLATBUSH AVENUE; For the Dollar Vans, a Gleam in the Eye

body: IF ever there was a time for Fort Greene, one of the most revered brownstone districts in Brooklyn, to have an identity crisis, that time would be now. Fort Greene is Brooklyn's latest culinary mecca, bewitching foodies with hip, minimalist restaurants. Or it's a bastion of African-American pride and culture, a historic home to a vibrant community
title: LIVING IN | FORT GREENE, BROOKLYN; Multiple Identities Can Be a Good Thing

body: AN ugly red statuette of a bull appeared last month on a shelf at O'Connor's, a sparsely decorated watering hole in Park Slope. Most of O'Connor's drinkers knew that the bull would fit in better at Freddy's Bar, a few blocks away in Prospect Heights. That's because the bull was, in fact, pilfered from Freddy's. The prank, carried out by an
title: PARK SLOPE | PROSPECT HEIGHTS; Pranksters Amid the Pilsner

body: THINK YOU KNOW The City's Streets? The New-York Historical Society's new Web site, Brooklyn Revealed, went public this week with a trove of history and trivia about the borough. title: CITY ROOM BLOGGING AT NYTIMES.COM/CITYROOM.

body: THE Erasmus Hall Academy building sits in a courtyard off Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn, mostly hidden from view by a quadrangle of Gothic public school structures that tower above the clothing stores and Caribbean restaurants on the street. The wood-framed building was constructed in 1786 as a school for the youth of Flatbush when the area, which
title: FLATBUSH; At a Fabled School, a Fixer-Upper

body: AROUND TOWN WILLIAMSBURG SPELLING BEE True confession time: I'm a spelling nerd. body: 'MAKE A LITTLE ROOM FOR ME!' What would small children do if an alligator invaded their classroom? Scream, no doubt -- but only with laughter, if the creature were the one that recently appeared at the 92nd Street Y. His teeth were no stronger than cardboard (in fact, they were cardboard) and his skull was suspiciously boxlike. And you had to pity
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: For two decades and more, Haiti, a land of grinding poverty, has endured coups, riots, a repressive military regime and hurricanes, travails that have often been overlooked beyond its borders. But one group of 60 Haitians, most of whom live in Brooklyn, has worked hard to maintain a bond with one small part of their homeland, becoming a lifeline of
title: In Brooklyn, Working to Help Their School in Haiti and Its City

body: Rusty Kanokogi learned to scrap when her name was still Rena Glickman and she wandered the Brooklyn boardwalk. She learned to struggle when her parents ignored her in a tiny house near Coney Island. She learned to attack when she discovered judo in a dojo on Flatbush Avenue. She learned to argue in plush offices when she lobbied for women's judo to
title: Fighter for Her Sport Has Own Battle

body: A few minutes after 6 a.m. Wednesday, the driver of a black sport utility vehicle called 911 from his cellphone to report that he had just hit someone on 108th Street in Corona, Queens. He went back to the spot. But there was no body there. At 7:05 a.m. in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, the driver of a red van noticed a pedestrian trying to flag him
title: Queens Driver Unknowingly Drags a Body Nearly 20 Miles

body: Afreen Juli, a senior at the Bronx High School of Science, applied early to Cooper Union, a college in Manhattan that specializes in engineering, art and architecture. title: Free College Has Allure Heightened By Economy

body: Shirley Fenelon doesn't seem like someone about to move for the third time in three years, who does not know who will care for her baby, due this month, when she goes back to work. She doesn't sound like a woman who endured the murder of her partner, leaving her with an infant daughter, and then a separation, several years later, from the father of
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; She's Become an Expert at Accentuating the Positive

body: Jabrilla English was 24 years old and nine months pregnant when she found herself living in a homeless shelter in the Bronx. Her sleepless nights there were haunted by the collective grumble of her sheltermates -- restless and downtrodden, so many women and families -- who took over slivers of the shelter's vast open space as their own. ''It was a
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Taking Responsibility For Herself and Her Son

body: Three generations of Thompsons gathered around the patriarch's dining room table in Brooklyn Heights the other day and gave three varied perspectives on the inauguration of Barack Obama. This prominent black political family from Brooklyn is headed by Harlem-born William C. Thompson. Known as Willie, he is 84 and served in a segregated infantry
title: A Historic Moment, Through One Prominent Brooklyn Family's Perspective
